snippet: By interrogating suspects before they are arraigned or have counsel assigned to them, the office of the Queens district attorney undermines the basic principle of Miranda.
abstract: Editorial criticizes Queens District Attorney Richard Brown for instituting a program that allows prosecutors to interrogate suspects before they are arraigned or have counsel assigned to them, essentially subverting the Miranda rule; praises New York State trial judge for challenging the program.
lead_paragraph: By interrogating suspects before they are arraigned or have counsel assigned to them, the office of the Queens district attorney undermines the basic principle of Miranda.
